column3: The Giants Who Built the Mount
column5: Cormoran, a giant, built St. Michael's Mount from huge stones carried from nearby granite hills, with the help of his Giantess wife, Cormelian, who did much of the laborious work. After catching Cormelian using greenstone instead of the required grey, Cormoran scolded her, resulting in her dropping the greenstone, which remains isolated and known as Chapel Rock.
Created the island in the middle of Lake Vättern
A 9 foot tall giant from Brussels folklore
Giant-king of wales, his cape was made from the beards of defeated kings.

Ashinaga and Tenaga, two fascinating yokai from Japanese folklore, symbolize the power of teamwork and adaptability. With Ashinaga’s long legs and Tenaga’s extended arms, they form an extraordinary partnership.

Colbrand, a legendary Danish giant of English folklore, was defeated by Sir Guy of Warwick to save Winchester from northern invaders. His legacy endured in literature, with mentions in Shakespeare's works and as a nickname for people of great size or strength in later centuries.
Ascapart, a 30-foot-tall giant from English folklore, was defeated by Sir Bevis of Hampton, who made him his squire before later killing him for betrayal.

Lydéric and Phinaert are semi-legendary figures linked to the founding of Lille around 640 AD. According to the tale, Lydéric avenged the murder of his parents (Prince Salvaert and Ermengaert) by slaying the giant Phinaert, then inherited his lands and established the city.

Daidarabotchi are colossal humanoids resembling bald-headed priests, with big, rolling eyes and pitch black skin. They possess immense strength, capable of building mountains by piling up rocks and dirt, and shaping the landscape with their massive footprints.

A Gashadokuro is a skeletal giant yōkai that wanders the countryside at night, making rattling sounds with its teeth and bones. It is said to be formed from the spirits of people who died in mass graves or due to famine, their anger and pain fueling its supernatural existence.

A wandering giant and the dwarf who rides in his pocket steal and eat sheep, tricking an angry wizard who owns the flock. The wizard later enslaves the giant to move hills and protect the land from flooding

William of Lindholme is portrayed in legend as a giant who accidentally kills sparrows and hurls huge stones at his parents, then strikes a deal with the Devil to build a marsh causeway that remains unfinished. He later vanishes from the world by burying himself alive, leaving scattered boulders and stories of demonic labour in his wake
